author: Jamie Bullen
title: Tube strike 2017: commuters braced for travel mayhem as Tube drivers walk out on 24-hour strike
text:
Wednesday 25 January 2017 21:30 BST Click to followThe Evening Standard Travel chaos: Thousands are expected to find alternative routes to work following a 24-hour Tube strike Jeremy Selwyn 
Tube drivers have walked out on a 24-hour strike which is set to bring chaos to hundreds of thousands of commuters. 
Workers staged industrial action at 9pm on Wednesday in protest over the “forced” transfer of eight drivers to different depots. 
As a result, the Waterloo & City line has completely shut down while on the Central line there are no services east of Leytonstone. 
A reduced service is running on the rest of the line all day Thursday which is expected to spark travel misery for travellers. 
The Central line is used by up to 800,000 passengers a day and the one-stop Waterloo & City line between Waterloo main line station and Bank by upwards of 32,000. 
Transport for London warned that some stations and routes will be “extremely busy”. 
Other lines are not affected but will be much busier than usual as passengers seek alternative routes to get to and from work – London Underground (LU) warned of queuing outside stations. 'Forced' transfer of just eight drivers triggers Tube strike 
Mick Cash, RMT general secretary, said: "RMT negotiators have made strenuous efforts through the Acas machinery to resolve this dispute but the door has been slammed in our faces. 
"If LU are allowed to get away with this move on the Central line they will start shunting drivers around at the drop of a hat regardless of the consequences." 
Steve Griffiths, London Underground's chief operating officer, said: "This strike is completely unnecessary. Everything you need to know about this week's Tube strike 
"Like any responsible transport authority we regularly examine how we can provide the best possible service to customers and to achieve this sometimes we need to move staff from locations where they are under-utilised, to the places where they are really needed. 
"We have agreements with the trade unions that enable us to do this. 
"Following a review on the Central line we identified eight train drivers on the east end of the line where there is not enough work for them and we have asked them to move to another line where their work would make a real difference and help give our customers a better service." 
Tube bosses are trying to prevent worse strike action from February 6 which would affect the entire network over a separate dispute involving station staff. More about:
